entry.title: Combined summary - 64 bit arithmetic soft fork
entry.summary:
The programming community is currently engaged in discussions over a new opcode `OP_ENABLE64BIT`, which would allow 8-byte inputs for arithmetic operations within scripting languages, borrowing concepts from liquid/elements. There are concerns about the potential complexities and risks of consensus splits it may introduce into script interpretersâ€™ consensus mechanisms. To reduce confusion, constraints such as making `ENABLE64BIT` fail if not placed first in the script sequence have been suggested.
Debates are ongoing on how to evolve the Script Virtual Machine (VM) while maintaining system accessibility and avoiding increased complexity or consensus risks. Proposals include modifying `CScriptNum` to support 64-bit numbers or enforcing an 8-byte standard for literals to circumvent malleability issues without changing `CScriptNum`. Discussions also involve endianness preference, with some advocating for big endian over little endian.
The proposed addition of `OP_ENABLE64BIT` could complicate the VM interpreter state by mixing standard and 64-bit operations within scripts. An alternative approach recommends interpreting all arithmetic operations as 64-bit using a `leaf_version` for consistency. However, this change could expand the VM state variable, complicating the state transition function and potentially increasing bugs affecting consensus. Despite skepticism, the benefits of expanding arithmetic support to 64-bit are recognized, especially if compatibility and network stability are ensured.
There is also a debate on encoding systems, weighing the current minimal-length big endian's compactness against proposals for mandated use of 64-bit operations. Moreover, covenant opcodes, specifically those enabling arithmetic on satoshi values, are considered for their potential to enhance functionality and flexibility in programming applications.
Cryptocurrency-related advancements focus on enhancing covenants with arithmetic operations to control transaction outputs, aiming to boost smart contract efficiency and sophistication. The shift toward 64-bit arithmetic in programming increases efficiency in functions like transaction hash operations, reflecting the industry's push for precision and complex data handling.
Furthermore, the importance of 64-bit arithmetic is highlighted by its role in enabling TLUV and possibly other protocols. A Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) advocating for the integration of 64-bit operations has been put forward for public review at [BIP proposal link](https://github.com/Christewart/bips/pull/1), with an associated implementation at [implementation link](https://github.com/Christewart/bitcoin/pull/2). Early feedback is being sought by the author to refine the proposal before presenting it to the broader community.
